discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] Request Minting of new MKR Tokens to Replace MKR Tokens Inadvertantly Sent to MKR Token Address (Burned)

content.content: Summary 3.1994 MKR Tokens were inadvertently sent to MKR Token Address. The purpose of this signal request is to notify the governance of the transaction and request new tokens be minted and returned to the sender, since the existing tokens are inaccessible.  Main Text A prior signal request was submitted on May 16th. This is a follow on signal request. The prior signal request clarified that the tokens in the MKR token address are inaccessible and therefore effectively burned. There were also multiple comments that listed this approach (mint new to replace old) as a viable path forward.     Request Return of MKR Tokens Inadvertantly Sent to Governance Address Signal Archive   Summary 3.1994 MKR Tokens were inadvertently sent to MKR Governance Address. The purpose of this signal request is to notify the governance authority of the transaction and request the tokens be returned to the sender.   Main Text On 2022-05-15 at 7:15:05 UTC, 3.1994 MKR were sent to MKR Governance Address 0x9f8F72aA9304c8B593d555F12eF6589cC3A579A2 from Coinbase. Transaction Hash: 54dccce86adcb209fe6305473fafd01d9dabac9508803cab094a5b0db4a8c638  Links to etherscan showing governance address and…     On 2022-05-15 at 7:15:05 UTC, 3.1994 MKR were sent to MKR Token Address 0x9f8F72aA9304c8B593d555F12eF6589cC3A579A2 from Coinbase. Transaction Hash: 54dccce86adcb209fe6305473fafd01d9dabac9508803cab094a5b0db4a8c638 Links to etherscan showing MKR token address and transaction hash below: https://etherscan.io/token/0x9f8f72aa9304c8b593d555f12ef6589cc3a579a2?a=0x9f8F72aA9304c8B593d555F12eF6589cC3A579A2 https://etherscan.io/tx/0x54dccce86adcb209fe6305473fafd01d9dabac9508803cab094a5b0db4a8c638 I am requesting that 3.1994 MKR tokens are minted and sent to the senders address of the transaction hash above on Coinbase. Note: This is a recurring issue that is going to continue to occur in the future. There are almost 800 MKR tokens that have been sent to the MKR Token Address.  Polls    Should 3.1994 new MKR Tokens be minted to replace tokens sent to MKR token address (burned)?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters      Next Steps Signal Request will run from. 2022-05-25T05:00:00Z→2022-06-08T05:00:00Z If signal request poll passes, then the poll will go onchain, asking MKR holders if they wish to mint 3.1994 new MKR tokens to replace tokens sent to MKR token address (burned). If signal request poll fails then no further action will be taken.

content.content: I understand your frustration, but I would rather not create a precedent where individuals are opening signal requests every time they accidently send MKR to the token address. If we do enact a solution, it needs to be something more automated and scalable.

content.content: My vote is NO, for one simple reason, we don’t want to leave a precedent of this and more people coming asking for this kind of things. MakerDAO should not be willing to wash their hands of their users for their problems, it would not be ideal to create dependency on someone making a mistake and the DAO coming to their rescue. We are human and we make mistakes, personally I would like that if a user makes a mistake maybe by contract as soon as a transfer is made to that wallet, maybe it will be reversed. And it will be returned automatically. It is the only thing I see viable in that sense.

content.content: As a long time blockchain user one of the key things people need to pay attention to is what my tx’s are going to do and realizing if I screw up I am in almost every case going to lose my tokens. Now you have to wonder what Maker governance would do if someone did this with 100K MKR.  So a real thought as to what to do generally (just like when 10M DAI was burned) that is fair in all cases should be undertaken.   I think a fee could be applied (some base fee + a percentage) for recovery. Without a real discussion in the DAO about a general solution here my usual reaction is to decline these requests.   Making me wonder what I had to say on the 10M DAI reimbursement.   But I am pretty sure my comments were very similar even though I voted yes to reimburse there.

content.content: In general the user must bear the responsibility of correct usage. As such I vote no for this as a one time solution. That being said behind every MKR or DAI lost to mistake is someone feeIing dejected and that can get turned off from using it more. This is why my opinion that we need a policy in place for situations like these. It was also my stance when we recovered the $10M lost. There was a draft of a policy and work being done, but somehow it never made it into fruition. This can be a good opportunity to pick up the thread.

content.content: My sympathies for your loss, but this could have been prevented and I don’t like the precedent this would create.

I think we can agree to disagree. Returning most of the funds require a non-trivial amount of work which is in part directly borne by all MKR holders. Especially more so if we were to make a regular reporting. I think it is reasonable to set a base fee and a certain percentage to be paid to the DAO for executing this work if we want to ever return it. This way we can also separate “trolls” from legitimate users who might want their funds back. I do not see how this can be a huge marketing opportunity. If at all, it may also make our DAO “seem” centralized.

content.content: GWintery:  This way we can also separate “trolls” from legitimate users   What kind of behavior would you classify as trolling?

In general, someone sending “dust” amounts to contracts and asking for it to be refunded. Whether it be DAI or MKR. Someone with too much time in their hands may also script this to make it easier for them to send from many addresses. Dust amount of course are relative, but if we want to give a blanket service to return all funds, I think this is an attack vector to be considered. Another way to mitigate is to only process returns above an arbitrary amount. I personally think a base fee will enforce this so a user will consider whether it is worth it or not to request a return of funds.
